title: A Stitch in Time
subtitle: Steve McGrail investigates the world of street theatre costume design.

cards.text: With the arrival of summer and autumn, the streets of Scotland's cities and towns are all of a sudden alive with historical characters: it is street theatre time, as the country's past is acted out in a series of Living History presentations and general historical re-creations. Street theatre has been growing in popularity for a decade and has made a significant contribution to the growth of the Scottish tourist industry.
cards.question: How is street theatre important to Scotland's cities and towns?
choices: It creates interest throughout the year.
It attracts visitors to the area.
It introduces new ideas about the past.
It teaches local people about their history.
cards.highlight: made a significant contribution to the growth of the Scottish tourist industry

cards.text: One of these new style costume makers is Sandra Morton, a freelance designer based at her home in Stirling, but working wherever costumes are needed.
cards.question: What do we learn about Sandra Morton's work as a designer?
choices: She is prepared to travel around.
She has been involved with street theatre for twenty years.
She prefers difficult projects.
She has had to move house.

cards.text: I've been making clothes for nearly twenty years, she says. Most of them have been a lot less complicated than what I'm making now. I just got a reputation for being good with my hands and I enjoyed what I did. I certainly enjoyed it more than my job in retail management.
cards.question: Compared with her previous job, Sandra says designing costumes is more
choices: profitable.
varied.
satisfying.
relaxing.
cards.highlight: I certainly enjoyed it more than my job in retail management

cards.text: The biggest issue, of course, is that our actors are usually right up close to the audience. In a normal theatre it's possible to get away with all sorts of things with costumes. I can't. Can you imagine what people would say if the 18th-century street-seller they were talking to had a jacket fastened with modern buttons? Or worse, if he had a couple of large safety-pins holding a tear together? It would be just no good!
cards.question: The problems that Sandra has with street theatre costumes are increased because
choices: the actors are often very critical.
suitable types of fastening are difficult to find.
nothing can be hidden from view.
old-fashioned fastenings do not work very well.
cards.highlight: nothing can be hidden from view

cards.text: David Kinnaird of the Heritage Events Company, based in Stirling, knows this only too well. The company is responsible for the town's well established street plays. 'We're increasingly using Sandra's work,' he explains, because she understands our particular needs. Think about the Scottish climate... Sandra is able to alter her designs and create costumes to survive a soaking.
cards.question: One reason why David Kinnaird employs Sandra is that she
choices: makes changes to suit his company's requirements.
knows a lot about dramatic performance.
is a leading expert in her field.
introduces him to useful new ideas.
cards.highlight: she understands our particular needs... is able to alter her designs

cards.text: Sandra experienced this difficulty during the baking hot summer of 1995. You have to be realistic about what you do... I was terribly proud of a soldier's uniform I made using woollen cloth lined with calico for stiffness - the traditional method. It looked wonderful, until the sun came out and the actor just melted. I haven't done that again.
cards.question: What did Sandra learn during the summer of 1995?
choices: Modern materials are capable of causing problems.
Actors are unwilling to deal with difficulties.
Street theatre is impossible in great heat.
Designers cannot always follow tradition.

cards.text: Because of their skills in re-interpreting the fashions of the past, Sandra and her colleagues believe the future looks bright. The Living History scene is constantly changing and there are always new needs and new challenges.
cards.question: How do street theatre designers in Scotland see their future?
choices: There will continue to be a demand for them.
The quality of their work will need to be improved.
They will need to concentrate on more specialised work.
They will need to revise their ideas on historical fashion.
cards.highlight: the future looks bright. The Living History scene is constantly changing and there are always new needs
